article.description:
Elton Brand had 26 points and 13 rebounds and Jeff McInnis scored 11 of his 16 points in the final nine minutes,
leading the Los Angeles Clippers to a 101-85 victory over the Sacramento Kings on Saturday night.
article.headline: Brand keys Clippers' victory over Kings
article.linkText: Clippers pick up league-best 14th home victory
article.story:
LOS ANGELES (AP) -- When it comes to up-tempo basketball, the Los Angeles Clippers have no peers -- especially on their home court.
Brand

Elton Brand had 26 points and 13 rebounds and Jeff McInnis scored 11 of his 16 points in the final nine minutes, leading the Clippers to a 101-85 victory over the Sacramento Kings on Saturday night. "That's been our whole mentality all year. We want to run," McInnis said. "That's no secret. Everybody knows we want to get up and down, and tonight we had a chance to do that a lot because they're the type of team that wants to do the same thing. So it was a track meet." The Clippers earned their league-leading 14th home victory. They have already won more home games than they did two seasons ago, when they moved into Staples Center after 15 seasons at the Sports Arena. It's the most victories for the Clippers this early in a season since they entered the league in 1970-71 as the Buffalo Braves. They didn't get their 14th home win last season until March 5. "I don't think we intimidate any teams at home. We just got the best of them tonight," McInnis said. "The Sacramento Kings are a great team, and we have to play them three more times. So I don't want to get too cocky." Coming off their first road victory of the season at Phoenix, and playing before their fifth home sellout, the Clippers won their third straight game and 10th in their last 13. They've won nine of 10 at home and 27 of 35 since last Feb. 1. "We're 15-11 already. I won only 15 games my whole season with the Bulls last year, so it's very amazing," Brand said. "I love being a Clipper." Michael Olowokandi had a season-high 13 points and grabbed 11 rebounds. It was the first time this season that Brand and Olowokandi each had a double-double in the same game. Doug Christie and reserve Bobby Jackson each had 19 points for the Kings, who have lost four straight on the road since beating San Antonio in overtime on Nov. 30. Sacramento is 6-8 away from home, after winning a franchise-record 22 road games last season. Chris Webber, limited to six games this season because of left ankle problems, missed his second straight game because of tendinitis in the ankle. Mateen Cleaves also sat out because of plantar fasciatis in his right foot. Kings center Vlade Divac had 12 points and 12 rebounds before picking up his second technical foul in a 2:54 span of the fourth quarter. "We didn't play well as a team," Divac said. "We didn't do a good job of positioning ourselves. We need to get back on defense. We are one of the best offensive teams, but offense does not win games." Olowokandi, who averaged only six field goal attempts and scored in double digits just four times through his first 25 games, had 10 points on 4-for-7 shooting in the first quarter and grabbed seven rebounds. "I felt good about it. I was called to do that and gave me the responsibility to start the game like that. So I tried to rise to the challenge," Olowokandi said. "The first plays coach drew up was to get the ball into me and to go at Vlade. We wanted to run him up and down the floor and take advantage of him. It was definitely orchestrated by the coach, and it paid off." The Clippers never trailed after Quentin Richardson hit a 3-pointer with 11 seconds left in the second quarter, giving Los Angeles a 49-48 halftime lead. Richardson finished with 20 points, including a pair of 3-pointers 32 seconds apart to extend the Clippers' lead to 95-80 with 3:57 left. Game notes
Olowokandi has not attempted a 3-point shot in 233 NBA games. The only active player who has appeared in more games from the start of his career without taking a shot from behind the arc is Minnesota's Dean Garrett (337 games). ... The Clippers have played 48 consecutive games without a 30-point scorer since last Feb. 27 at Sacramento, when McInnis had 33 against the Kings in a 106-93 overtime loss. ... The Clippers have beaten the Kings at least once in 25 consecutive seasons, their longest such streak against any team. The last time they were swept by them was 1976-77, when the Kansas City Kings took all three meetings with the Buffalo Braves.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
